keyTakeAways: The Trump administration proposed a compact with nine universities offering expanded federal funding in exchange for policy changes including removing sex and ethnicity from admissions and capping international enrollment.
Six universities — MIT, Penn, Brown, USC, Dartmouth, and UVA — have formally rejected the compact, citing concerns over academic freedom and institutional autonomy.

The compact includes ideological demands such as defining gender by biological processes, requiring faculty and staff to participate in annual anonymous polls, and enforcing a 15% cap on international students.
The White House claims signing would provide a competitive advantage in federal grants and access to White House events, but schools argue it undermines free inquiry and merit-based competition.
Schools like the University of Texas at Austin have not committed but expressed openness, while others like Vanderbilt and Arizona are reviewing the offer.
This proposal reflects a broader pattern of the Trump administration attempting to exert ideological control over universities, a central institution in American cultural and political life.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration has proposed a funding compact with nine U.S. universities, offering expanded federal grants and access to White House events in exchange for policy changes such as eliminating sex and ethnicity from admissions, capping international enrollment at 15%, and adopting biologically defined gender standards. Six universities — including MIT, Penn, Brown, USC, Dartmouth, and the University of Virginia — have formally rejected the proposal, citing violations of academic freedom and institutional autonomy. Others, such as Vanderbilt and the University of Arizona, are reviewing the offer, while the University of Texas at Austin has expressed openness. The White House claims the compact promotes a 'vibrant marketplace of ideas,' but universities argue that it undermines merit-based competition and free inquiry. This development reflects broader tensions between federal governance and academic independence in American higher education, with state officials like California Gov. Gavin Newsom adding additional pressure by threatening to withhold state funding.
title: Six Universities Reject White House Funding Deal with Attached Demands
